channel.title: Hierarchy of Node subclasses
channel.description:
In the process of writing an updater, it is now time to deal with objects, items, etc. I see in old updater output that they are all subclasses of something referred to as Node.
Now, which subclasses of Node will I find static arrays of in the client? I'm interested in the inventory array and objects/items in the currently loaded map region.

item.title: Hierarchy of Node subclasses
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

frank_:

finalising local variables would be an option, surely

It is. But why would you?

Read full topic

Especially with ‘final’ everywhere. What the hell is wrong with ins3?

There’s something called source clean up…

Unfortunately with eclipse its trivial to add final but hard to remove it unless you do a blanket search-replace.
[/quote]
That’s why I said it ;), those finals are added by source clean up.[/quote]
“clean up”.

item.title: Hierarchy of Node subclasses
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

frank_:

if you were confused by qauters’ post, OP, it is an example of what not to do

Don’t be a dick, it does exactly what it’s supposed to do. Besides 70% of that code can’t even be done differently, well if you want it to work that is.

BAsh:

Especially with ‘final’ everywhere. What the hell is wrong with ins3?

There’s something called source clean up…

Tekk123:

Thanks, that was helpful. I didn’t know the array of nodes was wrapped in a class.

Your welcome but yea that’s why you need to learn the client first

Read full topic

item.title: Hierarchy of Node subclasses
item.dc:creator: @Tekk123 Tekk
item.description:
@Tekk123 wrote:

[quote=“qauters, post:14, topic:308972”]If you don’t understand the basics, don’t start it :P. Also there’s something called rsbot lol:

	/**
	 * Returns all the ground items at a tile on the current plane.
	 */
	public RSItemTile[] getGroundItemsAt(final int x, final int y) {
		if (!isLoggedIn()) {
			return new RSItemTile[0];
		}

		final List<RSItemTile> list = new ArrayList<RSItemTile>();

		final org.rsbot.accessors.NodeCache itemNC = Bot.getClient().getRSItemNodeCache();
		final int sx = x - Bot.getClient().getBaseX();
		final int sy = y - Bot.getClient().getBaseY();
		final int id = sx | sy << 14 | Bot.getClient().getPlane() << 28;

		final org.rsbot.accessors.NodeListCache itemNLC = (org.rsbot.accessors.NodeListCache) findNodeByID(itemNC, id);

		if (itemNLC == null) {
			return new RSItemTile[0];
		}

		final NodeList itemNL = new NodeList(itemNLC.getNodeList());
		for (org.rsbot.accessors.RSItem item = (org.rsbot.accessors.RSItem) itemNL.getFirst();
				item != null; item = (org.rsbot.accessors.RSItem) itemNL.getNext()) {
			list.add(new RSItemTile(x, y, new RSItem(item)));
		}

		return list.toArray(new RSItemTile[list.size()]);
	}

[code]
public static Node findNodeByID(final org.rsbot.accessors.NodeCache nc, final long id) {
try {
if (nc == null || nc.getCache() == null || id < 0) {
return null;
}

		final Node n = nc.getCache()[(int) (id & nc.getCache().length - 1)];
		for (Node node = n.getPrevious(); node != n; node = node.getPrevious()) {
			if (node.getID() == id) {
				return node;
			}
		}
	} catch (final Exception e) { }

	return null;
}

[/code][/quote]

Thanks, that was helpful. I didn’t know the array of nodes was wrapped in a class.

Read full topic

item.title: Hierarchy of Node subclasses
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

If you don’t understand the basics, don’t start it :P. Also there’s something called rsbot lol:

	/**
	 * Returns all the ground items at a tile on the current plane.
	 */
	public RSItemTile[] getGroundItemsAt(final int x, final int y) {
		if (!isLoggedIn()) {
			return new RSItemTile[0];
		}

		final List<RSItemTile> list = new ArrayList<RSItemTile>();

		final org.rsbot.accessors.NodeCache itemNC = Bot.getClient().getRSItemNodeCache();
		final int sx = x - Bot.getClient().getBaseX();
		final int sy = y - Bot.getClient().getBaseY();
		final int id = sx | sy << 14 | Bot.getClient().getPlane() << 28;

		final org.rsbot.accessors.NodeListCache itemNLC = (org.rsbot.accessors.NodeListCache) findNodeByID(itemNC, id);

		if (itemNLC == null) {
			return new RSItemTile[0];
		}

		final NodeList itemNL = new NodeList(itemNLC.getNodeList());
		for (org.rsbot.accessors.RSItem item = (org.rsbot.accessors.RSItem) itemNL.getFirst();
				item != null; item = (org.rsbot.accessors.RSItem) itemNL.getNext()) {
			list.add(new RSItemTile(x, y, new RSItem(item)));
		}

		return list.toArray(new RSItemTile[list.size()]);
	}
	public static Node findNodeByID(final org.rsbot.accessors.NodeCache nc, final long id) {
		try {
			if (nc == null || nc.getCache() == null || id < 0) {
				return null;
			}

			final Node n = nc.getCache()[(int) (id & nc.getCache().length - 1)];
			for (Node node = n.getPrevious(); node != n; node = node.getPrevious()) {
				if (node.getID() == id) {
					return node;
				}
			}
		} catch (final Exception e) { }

		return null;
	}

Read full topic

item.title: Hierarchy of Node subclasses
item.dc:creator: @Tekk123 Tekk
item.description:
@Tekk123 wrote:

[quote=“Tekk123, post:1, topic:308972”]In the process of writing an updater, it is now time to deal with objects, items, etc. I see in old updater output that they are all subclasses of something referred to as Node.

Now, which subclasses of Node will I find static arrays of in the client? I’m interested in the inventory array and objects/items in the currently loaded map region.[/quote]

Never in my original post did I claim to know what Node was, I just said that I saw it being referred to in old updater output.

I realize that I was sort of annoyed in some of the posts above and made some contradicting statements.

I’m saying sorry, can we move on?

The fact still stands that I need some help on what the different things are that extend from Node.

Read full topic

item.title: Hierarchy of Node subclasses
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“Tekk123, post:10, topic:308972”][quote author=the bank link=topic=405429.msg2997721#msg2997721 date=1255735786]

how could your bot possibly need something if you dont know what it is ?

I know what a Node is. I’ve hooked it.

I want to know the subclasses of Node and what each does.
[/quote]Hooking something doesn’t mean understanding what it is, what it does and how it works.

Ok, maybe not, but the reason I posted this thread was because I wanted to LEARN about what Node and its subclasses do.[/quote]Then why on earth would you pretend to know? No one will want to help someone who claims to already know the answer. Be truthful with everything you say here.

Read full topic

most “things” are stored in jagex’s list implementation[/quote]
